intro: Acacia undosa, commonly known as the undulating acacia, is a shrub native to southern Africa. It is characterized by its slender, branching stems and phyllodes that are narrow and undulating in appearance. The plant produces yellow flowers in winter, which are arranged in cylindrical spikes. Its leaves are modified into phyllodes, a common adaptation in the Acacia genus to reduce water loss. Acacia undosa is often found in sandy or rocky soils and is adapted to arid and semi-arid environments.

Its genus is Acacia, a large group of shrubs and trees commonly found in arid regions, known for their needle-like leaves and often fragrant flowers. Its species is Acacia undosa, a specific type of acacia characterized by its unique morphology and ecological adaptations to its native environment.

It is commonly found in the southern regions of the state, particularly in the areas around the Fitzgerald River National Park and the Jarrahdale region. This species thrives in sandy soils and is often associated with coastal and inland habitats. It is well adapted to the dry and semi-arid conditions of its native range. Acacia undosa plays an important ecological role in stabilizing soils and providing habitat for local wildlife.
